item.title: Lecture 4
item.description:
Today’s Plan

  • 2.3 -> FTP
  • 2.4 Electronic Mail
    • How many parts in email delivery system
    • Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP)
    • Mail retrieval protocols:
      • POP3
      • IMAP
    • Basics of email security

How do people share data besides the Web?

  • FTP (FIle Transfer Protocol)
  • Email (for small-size data files)

Basics of FTP

  • Unlike HTTP, presents you a file system rather than a web page
  • Can browse remote host similar to a local file system
  • If allowed can
    • Upload files
    • Create directories
    • Other file system operations
  • FTP command =/= FTP protocol
  • telnet more exactly uses the low-level FTP protocol

FTP: the file transfer protocol

  • Specification: RFC 959
  • Client/server model
    • client: side that initiates file transfer (either get or put)
    • server: remote file storage host
      • Listening on TCP port 21

FTP: separate control, data connections

  • Client
    • Open a TCP connection with FTP server
    • Authorizes itself
    • Browse remote directory, issue get, put commands
  • Server
    • Listen on TCP port 21
    • When receives a file transfer command, opens a separate TCP data connection to client
    • After transferring each file, close the data connecion

FTP Questions

  • Is the retrieved data = the data stored in FTP?
    • Technically, no
  • Is it “safe” to use FTP?
    • Can be made safer using a checksum like MD5 (less secure) or SHA-256

Electronic Mail: 4 major components

  • user agents: aka “mail app”: composing, editing, reading mail messages
    • Eudora, Outlook, elm, Apple Mail, browser
  • mail servers:
    • mailbox contains incoming messages for user
    • message queue of outgoing (to be sent) mail messages
  • simple mail transfer protocol (SMTP): transfer email messages from user client to servers and between mail servers
  • mail retrieval protocls (multiple)

Example: Alice sends a amessage to Bob

  • Alice writes a msg “to” bob@someschool.edu
  • Alices UA sends message to her mail server; message placed in message queue
  • The mail server opens TCP connection with Bob’s mail server
  • Alice’s server sends the msg over the TCP connection
  • Bob’s mail server places the msg in Bob’s mailbox
  • Bob invokes his user agent to fetch message

Simple Mail Transfer Protocol

  • Three phases of transfer
    • Handshaking (greeting)
    • Transfer of messages
    • Closing
      • Note: this is not TCP connection close (to be covered in next lectures)
  • Each phase: command/respone interaction
    • commands: ASCII text
    • response: status code and phrase
  • Messages must be encoded in 7-bit ASCII

SMTP: A Few Highlights

  • SMTP server uses CRLF.CRLF to determine ned of message
  • SMTP msg body: use an empty line to separate header and body
  • Message must be encoded in 7-bit ASCII
  • Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) to support
    • Header information or text in non-ASCII charset
    • Non-text attachment
    • Message bodies with multiple parts

How to send emails?

  • SMTP servers for the domain normally allow emails only for this domain
  • Use “providers” SMTP service
    • Allow custmoers to send email to any domain service

Other way to send email?

  • Contact domain’s SMTP directly
  • Drawbacks?

Securing channel to SMTP server

  • Remember HTTPS
  • Similar can/should be used for SMTP
    • Don’t allow others to see your login password

Is your email secure?

  • No
  • Why?
    • Its just plain text

Is there any way to secure your email?

  • How to ensure that others know your email is indeed from you?

Securing Email

  • Sign with a valid certificate
    • Issued by some certification authority
      • Can check and vouch that it is indeed you who sent the email
      • Can simply check your own email
    • Web-of-Trust certificate (PGP, GPG)
      • Others can vouch for you
  • Encrypt with somebody else’s public key

Signing outgoing emails

  • Manually
    • Gmail and most other web-based systems
  • Automatically
    • Apple Mail, Outlook, etc.

Verification

  • Manually
    • GPG + paste text and signature
  • Automatically
    • With desktop mail client

Mail access protocols

  • SMTP: deliver mail to receiver’s server
  • Mail access protocol: retrieval from server
    • POP: Post Office Protocol [RFC 1939]
      • Authorization (agent <–> server) and download
    • IMAP: Internet Mail Access Protocol [RFC 1730]
      • More feature (e.g. multiple folders)
      • manipulation of stored messages on server
    • HTTP: Gmail, Hotmail, Yahoo! Mail

item.title: Lecture 3
item.description:
Plan for Today

  • Non-persistent vs persistent HTTP, pipelining
  • HTTP cookies
  • HTTP caching
  • HTTP/2.0: a brief introduction

Non-persistent HTTP: Response Time

  • RTT (round-trip time): time between client sending a small packet to server and receiving reply
  • Response time for fetching one object:
    • One RTT to set up TCP connection
    • One RTT for HTTP request and first byte of HTTP response to reach the client
    • Object transmission time
  • Total = 2 RTT + transmission time

Loading a webpage (with non-persistent HTTP)

  • First client requests and receives the HTML page
  • If there are images on the page, the client makes more requests for each image
  • Essentially for a page with 2 images
    • We would set up 1 TCP connection to get the page
    • Then set up an additional TCP connection for each image

Q: How to improve?

  • What we have now: at most one object is sent over one TCP connection
  • Could open multiple parallel TCP connections
  • Could keep TCP connection open, use it to fetch/send multiple objects (persistent HTTP)

Persistent HTTP

  • After sending out first object, keep the connection open for a short period, so if there is another reqeust it can use the same connection

HTTP Summary

  • Non-persistent HTTP
    • At most one object is fetched over a single TCP connection
    • HTTP/1.0 uses nonpersistent TCP connection
      • Described in RFC 1945
  • Persistent HTTP
    • Multiple objects can be sent over a single TCP connection between client and server
    • HTTP/1.1 uses persistent connections
      • Described in RFC 2616
  • Either persistent or non-persistent HTTP can set up multiple TCP connections in parallel to speed up data fetching

Persistent HTTP: one more detail

  • Persistent without pipelining:
    • Client issues new request after previous response has been received
    • Total delay: one RTT for each object plus data transfer time
  • Persistent with pipelining:
    • Client sends requests as soon as it sees a referenced object
    • Total delay: one RTT plus data transfer time for all objects

Three factors in HTTP fetching

  • Use persistent connection or not
  • Set up parallel connections or not
  • Use pipelining in connections or not

HTTP Cookies

  • If HTTP servers are stateless, how come websites (amazon, google, etc.) and services (advertisements) can remember me?
    • You are being tracked
  • Client stores cookies and sends them along with the initial GET request during the next TCP connection with the server

Cookies make use of these ingredients:

  • Website:
    • If an HTTP request does not have a “cookie” field, include a “set-cookie” header line in HTTP response message
    • Storing in back-end database the cookie with info about the user’s requests

Cookies: usefulness versus privacy

  • Cookies can
    • Bring convenience to you
    • Bring recommendations
    • Permit a website to learn a lot about you
    • Advertising companies can obtain user info across multiple sites

Web Caching (IMPORTANT)

  • User sets browser to enable web accesses via cache
  • Browser sends all HTTP requests to cache
  • Cache:
    • If requested object in cache: returns object
    • Else requests object from the server, then returns object to client

Why Web Caching

  • Reduce load on the origin server
    • Enables “poor” content providers to effectively deliver content
  • Reduce traffic on an institution’s access link
  • Reduce response time for client request

Example: without caching

  • Assumptions
    • Average web request rate = 10 req/sec
    • Average object size = 100,000 bits
    • RTT from institutional router to any web server and back 500 msec
  • Consequences
    • Utilization on LAN = 10%
    • Utilization on acces link = 100%
      • Queueing delay at institutional router: may grow without bound
  • Total delay = 500 msec + long queueing delay

Solution 1: Buy more bandwidth

  • Increase bandwidth of access link to 10 Mbps
  • Consequences:
    • Can be costly
    • Utilization on LAN = 10%
    • Utilization on access link = 10%

Solution 2: Adding a local cache

  • Consequences:
    • Assume hit rate = 0.4: 40% of requests will be satisfied by the data in the cache (delay = 10 msec)
    • Remaining 60% requests served by origin servers
    • Utilization of access link reduced to 60% -> much smaller queueing delay (say 30 msec)
    • Average delay for each packet = 0.6 x (Internet delay + access delay) + 0.4 x (LAN/cache delay) = 0.6 x (5s0 msec) + 0.4 x (10 msec) = 322 msec

Having a local cache: Not a free lunch

  • Need to configure browsers to use the local cache
  • What if the local cache fails?
  • What if the cached content is obsolete?
  • What about secure HTTP connections?

HTTP Conditional GET

  • Fetch content only if it has changed since previous fetch
  • Cache: specify date of cached copy in HTTP request
    • “If-modified-since: "
  • Server: response contains no object if cached copy is up-to-date
    • “HTTP/1.1 304 Not Modified”

Why HTTP 2.0

  • HTTP/1.1 with pipelining: not good enough
  • Some measurement numbers: an average Web application is now
    • Composed of more than 90 objects
    • Fetched from more than 15 distinct hosts
    • Totalling more than 1,300 KB of transferred data
      • On average each object < 15 KB
      • Some can be very big
      • That means some others can be very small

Some of HTTP/1.1’s Performance Issues

  • Pipelining: not supported by default
    • Consequence: take on RTT to fetch ech object
    • Work-around: app developers bundle multiple small objects into a big one
  • Head-of-line blocking: HTTP/1.1 handles requests in strict sequential order
    • A request for a large file, or some dynamic computation, can take time, blocking all requests after it
    • Work-around: open multiple TCP connections
  • Big HTTP header with repetitive information
    • No way to get around this

HTTP/2.0: binary framing

  • HTTP requests changed to have two frames:
    • HEADERS frame
    • DATA frame

HTTP/2.0: header compression

  • Both browser and server keep a header table until the TCP connection closes
  • Don’t resend headers that have not changed

HTTP/2.0: frame, message, stream

  • Frame: basic communication unit
  • Message: an HTTP request or response (using one or multiple frames)
  • Stream: a virtual channel with priority, carrying messages between client and server

HTTP/2.0 Multiplexing

  • Only need a single TCP connection between HTTP clietn and server
  • The connecton can carry multiple stream

HTTP/2.0 Performance Improvements

  • Reduce HTTP header overhead
    • Binary encoding
    • Header compression
  • Single TCP connection between each client-server pair
    • Multiple stream
    • Each stream: deliver messages between HTTP client–server
    • Big messages are broken down to multiple frames
    • Frames from all streams can be interleaved

HTTPS: Secure HTTP

  • Ensure that you’re receiving data from place you think you do
  • Ensure secrecy of information exchanges

HTTPS: Sites with Domain Validation (DV) Certificates

  • Contains proof that a public key belongs to a particular public party
  • Less secure than EV

HTTPS: Sites with Extended Validation (EV) Certificates

  • The Certificate Authority (CA) checks the right of the applicant to use a specific domain name PLUS it conducts a THOROUGH vetting of the organization
  • Can also check certificate manually by clicking the lock icon in a browser

item.title: Discussion 1
item.description:
Tentative Schedule

  • Week 1
    • Intro to project 1
    • Basic socket programming
  • Week 2
    • HTTP abstraction
  • Week 3
    • Concurrent connections
  • Week 4
    • Midterm review
  • Week 5
    • Project 1 Q&A

Overview of Project 1

  • Project webpage
    • Ready for your to start
    • More hints and sample code will be added
  • Vagrant
    • A easy way to use virtual machine
  • Wireshark
    • Debug tool: monitor network traffic

Socket Programming: What is a Socket?

  • An inter-process communication mechanism
    • Processes may be on the same host or different hosts
  • An abstract I/O interface to applications
    • Similar to file I/O
    • Hide implementation details to low-level layers

Revisit File I/O Interface

  • Unix/Linux model I/O devices as files
    • Input: read from a “file”
    • Output: write into a file”
  • Each “file” has an identifier: file descriptor
    • An integer
    • Three standard fds
      • 0 for stdin
      • 1 for stdout
      • 2 for stderr
  • To interact with I/O devices
    • Obtain fd
    • Read from or write into fd

Read/Write

  • read() - normal system call
    • buf: buffer to hold data
    • count: size of data to read
    • return: size of data has been read to buffer
  • write() - normal system call
    • buf: buffer to hold data
    • count: size of data to write
    • return: size of data has been written to buffer

Socket is also “file”

  • Model network connection as a file
    • Read from the file: receive data from the connection
    • Write into the file: send data to the connection

Create Sockets

  • socket()
    • domain: specifies the protocol family (L3 network layer)
      • AF_INET for IPv4 Internet Protocols
    • type: specifies the communcation semantics (L4 network layer)
      • SOCK_STREAM for TCP
      • SOCK_DGRAM for UDP
      • SOCK_RAW for UDP
    • protocol: specifies a particular protocol in a domain to be use
    • return: sockfd, a file descriptor for the new socket

Bind address to a socket

  • bind()
    • sockfd: which socket to bind
    • addr: which address to bind
    • addrlen: size of address

Network byte order

  • Different hardware use different byte ordering
    • Intel: little endian
    • Solaris: big endian
  • Network byte order is big endian
    • For two different machines to communicate, conversion is needed
  • Code should be portable
    • Helper functions

Listen to incoming connections

  • listen() - inform OS to listen any incoming connections to this socket
    • sockfd: which socket is listening
    • backlog: how many incoming connections can be queued (for the project just put some number)
    • return: 0 for success, -1 for error
  • Does not start a connection

Initiate a connection

  • connect() - try to connect to server
    • sockfd: socket at local side
    • addr: address of peer socket
    • addrlen: size of peer socket address
    • return: 0 for success, -1 for error

Accept a connection on a socket

  • accpet() - establish a connection and create a new socket for it
    • sockfd: the listening socket
    • addr: address of peer socket
    • addrlen: size of peer socket address
    • return: new socket descriptor for the accepted connection
      • The socket used for data transmission
  • Socket return by accept is different from the listening socket!

item.title: Lecture 2
item.description:
Covered in Lecture 1

  • Internet: made of a huge number of hosts and routers, interconnected by physical and wireless links
  • Hosts: run bunch of protocols to exchange data with each other
  • Routers: run bunch of protocols to exchange data with each other
  • Protocols are organized in layers
    • Application protocols
    • Transport protocols
    • Network protocols
    • Link layer protocols
  • How to calculate packet delays as they move across a network

Data Delivery Performance

  • 3 basic measurements
    • Delay (sec, msec)
    • Throughput (bits/sec, Kbps, Mbps, Gbps)
    • Loss rate (% of packets that did not make it)
  • Transmission delay: L / R
    • R = link bandwidth (bps)
    • L = packet length (bits)
  • Propagation: d / s
    • d = length of physical link
    • s = propagation speed in medium (~2 x 10^8 m/sec)
  • Queueing delay = # packets in queue x transmission time of each packet

Lets Try an Example

  • A —- R —-> S1 ——– 2R ——–> S2 —- R —-> B
  • L = 4000 bits, R = 2 Mbps, A sends 4 packets
    • L / R = 2 ms, L / 2R = 1 ms
  • Propagation delay: 2 ms for each link
  • When will the first packet get to S2?
    • A – S1: D_transmission + D_propagation = 2 ms + 2 ms
    • S1 – S2: D_transmission + D_propagation = 1 ms + 2 ms = 3 ms
  • When the first packet arrives at S2, where is the second packet?
    • This occurs at t = 7 ms
    • At t = 4 ms, last bit leaves A
    • At t = 6 ms, last bit arrives at S1
    • At t = 7 ms, last bit leaves S1

A summary: Where is the Packet?

  • A ————> B
    • Bandwidth: W,
    • Link length: 200 km
    • Packet size: 1000 bits
  • Q: when the first bit of the packet reaches B, where is the last bit?
    • P = propagation delay = 200,000 m / 2 x 10^8 m/sec = 1 ms
  • If transmission delay = P (W = 1 Mbps)
  • If transmission delay = 0.1 P
    • bandiwdth * propagation delay = amount of data in the pipe

Chapter 2: Application Layer

  • Principles of network applications
  • Web and HTTP
  • FTP
  • Electronic Mail
  • DNS
  • P2P applications
  • Socket programming (covered in section)

Some Population Network Applications

  • Email
  • Web
  • Instant messaging
  • P2P file sharing
  • Multi-user network games

Client-server application communication model

  • Servers:
    • Reachable by IP address
    • Always-on, waiting for incoming requests from clients
  • Clients:
    • Initiate communication with server
  • Q: How does a client process identify the server process with which it wants to communicate?
  • A: using port numbers via the socket API

A quick comment about “port”

  • Web, email, ftp all use TCP
  • How does the server tell who wants what?
    • By port number: web uses port 80, ftp uses 21, and email uses 25

Socket

  • Process: program running on a host
  • Between different hosts: processes communcate through an application-layer protocol
  • A process sends/receives messages to/from its socket
  • Socket analogous to door:
    • Sending process shoves message out of the door
    • Transport protocol brings message up to the socket from the process

What is “Socket”

  • A set of system function calls
    • socket() - create a socket
    • bind() - bind a socket to a local IP address and port #
    • connect() - initiating connection to another socket
    • listen() - passively waiting for connections
    • accept() - accept a new connection
    • write() - write data to a socket
    • read() - read data from a socket

Establishing a socket on the client side

  • Create a socket with the socket() system call
  • Connect the socket to the server using the connect() system call
  • Send and receive data
    • There are a number of ways to do this, but the simplest is to use the read() and write() system calls

Establishing a socket on the server side

  • Create a socket with the socket() system call
  • Bind the socket to [address, port #] using the bind() system call
  • Listen for connections with the listen() system call
  • Accept a connection with the accept() system call
    • This call typically blocks until a client connects with the server
  • Send and receive data

Applications

  • So far we’ve talked about
    • Application process (executing application program)
    • Application protocol (used by application processes to exchange data)
    • Exactly how data is exchanged
      • Socket
      • Transport protocol
    • Lets look at exactly what data is exchanged

Web and HTTP

  • Web page: normally consists of
    • Base HTML-file, which includes several referenced objects
  • An object can be another HTML file, JPEG image, Java applet, audio file, …
  • Each object is addressable by a URL (Universal Resource Locator)

HTTP: HyperText Transfer Protocol

  • Web’s application layer protocol
  • Client/server model
    • Client: browser that requests, recieves, and displays web objects
    • Server: web server sends objects in response to requests
  • HTTP/1.0: non-persistent connection
  • HTTP/1.1: persistent connection
    • May also use pipelining

More on HTTP

  • Uses TCP:
    • Client initiates TCP connection (creates socket) to server, port 80
    • Server accepts TCP connection from client
    • HTTP messages (application-layer protocol messages) exhanged between browser (HTTP client) and web server (HTTP server)
    • TCP connection closed
  • HTTP is “stateless”
    • Server maintains no information about past client requests
  • Aside: protocols that maintain “state” are complext
    • Past history (state) must be maintained if server/client crashes, their views of “state” may become inconsistent

HTTP Request MEssage

  • Two types of HTTP messages: request, response
  • HTTP request message:
    • ASCII (human-readable)
    • Request line: method, url, veresion, \r, \n
      • “GET /index.html HTTP/1.1\r\n”
    • Header lines
    • Blank line at the end indicates end of header

Method Types

  • HTTP/1.0
    • GET
    • POST
    • HEAD
      • Requesting the header only (i.e. response does not include the requested object)
  • HTTP/1.1
    • GET, POST, HEAD
    • PUT
      • Uploads file in entity body to path specified in URL field
    • DELETE
      • Deletes file specifie in the URL field from the server
    • And a few others
      • See te protocol specification in RFC2616

HTTP Response Message

  • Status line
    • “HTTP/1.1 200 OK\r\n”
  • Header lines
  • Blank line indicating end of header
  • Data, e.g., requested HTML file

HTTP Response Status Codes

  • Appears in the first line in server -> clinet response message
  • A few sample codes
    • 200 OK
      • Request succeeded, requested object later in this message
    • 301 Moved Permanently
      • Requested object moved
    • 400 Bad Request
    • 404 Not Found
      • Requested document not found
    • 505 HTTP Version Not Supported

Trying out HTTP Request for Yourself

  1. Telnet to a Web server
  2. Type in a GET HTTP request
  3. Look at response message from the HTTP server

item.title: Lecture 1
item.description:
What is a computer network?

  • IP protocol, etc

CS 118: Explain to you how internet works

  • Divide-and-conquer
    • Internet: a very large and complex system
    • First: figure out many major parts
    • Then: learn one part at a time
  • Your job:
    • Read the textbook, think through
    • Ask questions
    • Practice from doing your homeworks and projects

Course Workload

  • Weekly reading assigmments (starting today)
  • Weekly homework assignments
    • Available from CCLE every Thursady starting this week, due the following Wednesday
  • Two programming Projects
    • Work in a team (up to 3 people in each time)
  • Midterm: Thursday, April 28 (in class)
  • Final: Monday, June 6, 2016, 6:30pm - 9:30pm

Course Grading

  • 16% Weekly homework assigments (8 total)
  • 40% for 2 programming projects
    • 1st: 20%, 2nd 20%
  • 22% Midterm exam
  • 22% Final exam

Strict Grading Policy

  • No credit for late homework or projects

First step: Big Picture & Terminology

  • Millions of connected computing devices
    • hosts = end systems
    • running network apps
  • Communication links
    • fiber, copper, radio, satellite
    • transmission rate: bandiwdth
  • Packet switches: forward packets (chunks of data)
    • routers and switches

“Nuts and Bolts” view

  • Internet: “network of networks”
    • Interconnected ISPs
  • Protocols control sending, receiving of msgs
    • e.g., TCP, IP, HTTP, Skype, 802.11
  • Internet standards
    • RFC: request for comments
    • IETF: Internet Engineering Task Force

Application’s View of Networking

  • Web browser <——- Internet ——-> Web server
  • These are application programms
  • They talk to each other using application protocols (for web, protocol = HTTP)
  • Don’t know or care how data is sent; do care whether it is delivered reliably
  • Runs on top of transport protocols

What’s a Protocol

  • Human protocols
    • “what’s the time”
    • “I have a question”
    • introductions
  • Network protocols
    • Machines rather than humans
    • All communication activity in Internet govered by protocols
  • Protocols define format, order of messages sent and received among network entities, and actions taken on message transmission, receipt
  • … specific messages sent
  • … specific actions taken when messages received or other events
  • Network protocol
    • TCP connection request –> TCP connection response –> GET http://www.google.com –> -->

Application Layer Protocols

  • Covered in chapter 2 of the book
  • Basic objective: understand common application protocols:
    • Web: Hyper-Text Transfer Protocol (HTTP)
    • Email: Simple Mail Transport Protocol (SMTP)
    • Domain Name System (DNS)
  • More important objective: design issues
    • What kinds of services required from the network
    • How does the choice of services impact application design?

Transport View of Networking

  • Assuming application protocols take care of data content
  • Transport protocol’s job: delivering data between communicating ends
  • Don’t know or care bout which paths data may traverse through the network
  • Do care about:
    1. Delivering data to the right application process
    2. Delivery reliability
    3. Congestion control

Transport Layer Protocols

  • Unreliable data delivery: UDP (User Datagram Protocol)
  • Reliable data delivery: TCP (Transport Control Protocol)
    • Reliable delivery over potentially unreliable network
    • Understanding and managin network delays
    • Coping with congetstion
  • But transport protocols don’t really do the delivery

Network Layer’s view of the picture

  • Assuming higher layer protocols handle data content, reliability and congestionm
  • Network’s job: forward data from source to destination
  • Do care about: which way to forward data at each step?
  • Why is this hard? Because the Internet is huge!

Internet Connectivity

  • Consider the connection from laptop to CNN.com:
    • Wi-Fi -> campus backbone -> ISP -> other ISP -> CNN website
  • Access Networks
    • Connect end system to local network
    • Some local network router connects to ISP router
  • ISP interconnect with each other to form the Internet

Network Layer PRotocols

  • Covered in Chapter 4 of the textbook
  • There are different types of networks
    • Circuit-switched versus packet-switched
  • Internet: packet-switched networks
    • Network layer provides best effort delivery of packets
  • Don’t care exactly how a packet is delivered from one node to next
    • That’s the job for link layer protocls

Link layer protocols

  • Link can be twisted pair, coaxial cable, fiber optic, or wireless
  • Link layer job: get a packet sent across some medium
    • Different medium -> different link layer protocol
  • Covered in Chapter 5 and 6.1 - 6.3 of the text
    • Borders on Electrical Engineering: running on top of physical layer
  • Our objective is to understand technology
    • How the network is built
    • How do link layer features impact higher layers design

Internet Protocol Stack

  • Application layer
  • Transport layer
  • Network layer
  • Link layer
  • Physical layer

Packet Switching: Multiplexing, Queuing Delay, Loss

  • Queuing and loss:
  • If arrival rate (in bits) to link exceeds transmission rate of link for a period of time:
    • Packets will queue, wait to be transmitted on link
    • Packets can be dropped (lost) if memory (buffer) fills up

Data Delivery Performance

  • 3 basic measurments
    • Delay (sec, msec)
    • Throughput (bits/sec)
    • Loss rate (% of packets lost)
  • Measure at different points -> different results

Packet Losses

  • Loss due to transmission errors
  • Loss due to congestion
  • Wireless links: variety of possible issues

Throughput

  • Throughput over a single link
    • Point-to-point
      • Pumping data to the pipe: link bandwidth
    • Multi-access
  • Throughput between two end hosts

Delay in packet-switched networks

  • 4 sources of delay at each hop
    • Nodal processing:
      • Check bit errors
      • Determine output link
    • Queuing = # packets in queue X transmission time of each packets
    • Transmission = L / R
      • L = packet length (bits)
      • R = link bandwidth (bps)
    • Propagation = d / s
      • d = length of physical link
      • s = propagation speed in medium

Example: one hop delay

  • Details:
    • link length = 100 km
    • bandwidth = 1 Mbps
    • packet size = 1000 bits
    • All packets equal length
  • Queuing delay = Waiting time for 2 packets
  • Transmission delay = 1000 bits / 1000000 bits/sec = 0.001 sec = 1 msec
  • Propagation delay = 100000 m / 2 * 10^8 m/s = 0.0005 sec = 0.5 msec

Packet-switching: store-and-forward

  • Takes L / R seconds to transmit packet of L bits on to link of R bps
  • Entire packet must arrive at router before it can be transmitted on next link: store and forward

Network Latency

  • Time to send 1 packet from point A to point B
    • Sum of delays across each hop along the path
    • Delay_A-B = Delay_A-1 + Delay_1-2 + Delay_2-B
  • RTT = round-trip-time

Real internet delays and routes

  • What do “real” internet delay and loss look like?
  • traceroute program: provides delay measurement from source to router along end-end Internet path towards destination. For all i:
    • Sends three packets that will reach router i on path towards destination
    • Router i will return packets to sender
    • Sender times interval between transmission and reply
  • RTT =/= 2 * Oneway Delay traceroute
